div.p:
A welcome, more welcome
more delightfully welcome
to me could not have met
my eyes than the note in
your own dear handwriting

I hope it did not give you
horrid pain to write it?
And so much! and so well
written as if you had never
been ill -- whatever it cost you
believe me you have given
me heartfelt pleasure and
more than pleasure - satisfaction.

Harriet Beauforttold you yes
terday yesterday whatCramptonsays
about the care you ought to take
not to exert yourself or to do any
thing that distresses you standing
sitting -- or moving -- How angry
he would have been had he
four pages in your own hand.

Dearestmotherthank you
thank you - I will not give you an
opportunity of doing the like again
for I will be with you soon & then
you can only sin by talking or hearing too
much

I leftLondonwithout any anxiety
aboutFannyas I had to the very
last day and hour satisfactory
accounts of her progressing - or
or at least of her not back-sliding
I enclose twobillet douxfrom her
& of her for the pleasure of your
eyes -

I set off fromLondon, from the
Railroad station at 9 oclock -

KindLestockhaving brought me
bag & baggage and all to the right
point at the right minute and
there wasCharles Foxready for me
having taken our two places in the
Coupee - Only costs 2Sh a piece more
than in the 1sclass other carriages &
it is delightfully comfortable - as
good as any gentleman's chariot
is or need to be & as dear & large
windows & green curtains & all that
most luxuriousexclusivecould want
or wish for excluding sun into the bargain
or not as you like - A most pleasant
journey I had - the easiness of the
motion on the rail way from
Birming
ham Birmingham
ham toLiverpoolresting me complete
ly after the roughness and great
joggling of the rail-road from
LondontoBirmingham-Francis
may remember that I observed this
difference when I travelled with
him & now I have verified it. Tho
we came all through in one day
fromLondontoLiv.l I was not the
least tiredarrived at 1/2 after 5 atLiverpool - We had but just time
to get fromLivl Rail road station in
fly to steam packet & byC Fox'smanual
exertions to get my 4 boxes & 1 bag
& his own (including two rolls of window
curtain chintz of his, so barba
rously barbarously ill done up that they
were forever slipping out
of theirsilverpaper only covering

The RecorderF. Shaw&Col.lConolly, and
Sir William Betham& 2 other members of
parl. (names forgotten) were on board
the packet & gathered roundCharles&
me - and talked an immensity of politics
&c-Peeland Dissolution &c &c - Literature
& compliments for me interspersed
more than quantum suff - And I
was glad at last even to get down to
my close birth - with 2 quakers & their
bonnets and a lovely contrastin colors- all very quiet
and all fell fast asleep - And nobody
stirred till morning 6 oclock & a very
fine morning and as calm a night
as would be -a ten & half hours
passage -

C Foxbrought me to this nice house
and dearHarrietready dressed at
the door by 1/4 before 8 - and she
welcomed me with her own smiles
and your note - I had had coffee before
I quitted Steampacket - So no hurry for
breakfast & tookHarrietsadvice & lay
down for half an hour & then washed
